ygData.subject: Re: Problem solved
ygData.msgSnippet: Matthias, glad to hear it s been solved.  About your new question, I would suggest avoiding randomness when possible, even if it means a bit more evaluation.

Matthias, glad to hear it's been solved.  About your new question, I
would =
suggest avoiding randomness when possible, even if it means a
bit more eval=
uation.  However, note that you may not need actually 15
different trials t=
o get good generalization, even if it is not random.
 I do not know the exa=
ct number of course, but the rule of thumb with
generalization is that if i=
t is easier for it to learn the general
principle than it is for it to memo=
rize each individual case (even if
they are deterministic) then it will lik=
ely produce a general answer
even without random trials.  On the other hand=
, randomness introduces
noise, for which evolutionary algorithms pay a heav=
y price in efficiency.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "matthias.linhard=
t" <faulerlennert@...>
wrote:
>
> Hello everyone,
> 
> I have finally found=
 the mistake I made. Between samples, the arm's 
> speed in the simulator w=
as not set back to 0, resulting in the arm 
> starting each sample with the=
 kinetic energy of the last sample.
> Since the correction of this mistake,=
 everything works fine and NEAT 
> produces very good results. 
> I want to=
 thank everyone who tried to help me with this!
> 
> Thanks,
> Matthias
> 
=
> PS: Now that I finally can evolve arm controllers, I have another 
> ques=
tion. To get a controller with high ability to adopt to new 
> situations, =
would it be better to train all organisms with a high 
> number of training=
 samples (e.g. 15 different start goal positions) 
> or with a low but each=
 generation randomly changed number of samples 
> (e.g. 3 start goal positi=
ons which are randomly generated each 
> generation)?
>
